item.title: New Report Claims Switch 2 Third-Party Game Launch Numbers Are Pretty Bad
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/nintendo-switch-2-third-party-game-launch-sales-report

A new report claims that launch numbers for third-party games available on the newly-released Nintendo Switch 2 aren't great, and that customers seem to be favoring Nintendo's own games rather than those by publishers like Capcom, CD Projekt, and Sega.

According to The Game Business, around 62% of physical Switch 2 game sales in the US during the console's launch week were for first-party games, and that doesn't include the Mario Kart World console bundle, which comes complete with a digital copy of the racer.

The Game Business notes that "one third-party publisher" (who the publication doesn't name) referred to Switch 2 launch sales as "below our lowest estimates", so it sounds like non-Nintendo publishers releasing games on the Switch 2 aren't happy with sales so far.

As The Game Business points out, while Switch 2 third-party numbers might look better than the original Switch's figures (81% physical first-party during the launch month), those figures should come with some caveats.

More third-party games launched alongside the Switch 2 - thirteen versus the original console's five - and the Switch 2 has also sold more consoles than the original machine did during the same time period, so the higher percentage doesn't tell the whole story.

It's difficult to know what, if anything, these figures portend. Many of the Switch 2's third-party titles are several years old, meaning a lot of people will probably already have had their fill of them.

Additionally, the Switch 2's strange Game Key Card system, which means that many publishers don't actually include full game files on their Switch 2 carts, may have put off buyers from picking up games on Nintendo's platform. It's difficult to say without more in-depth qualitative data, of course.

As newer Switch 2 games and third-party exclusives (assuming such releases are planned by publishers) begin to arrive, we'll probably get a more complete picture of how people feel about Switch 2 third-party titles.

Still, Nintendo probably isn't too worried; it's always the company's first-party releases that do the best on Nintendo hardware, and as long as games like Mario Kart World, the two Zelda Switch 2 Editions, and the upcoming Donkey Kong Bananza enjoy strong sales, Nintendo probably won't sweat too much.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
